comments.commentBody: On Sunday when we meet, I'll be halfway to the devil (or at least his number). So I don't mind it. I know I wrote sal/Leona, and I got the music and the star. It's just that when I "review" the puzzle, there's a "p" there...
trump is boring when he's being presidential, and toxic when he's being trump. sad.
Somewhere, there's a bus with gold plated fixtures and velvet seats, just waiting for him to get onboard.  It's the bestest bus.

You are underestimating the enemy.

Trump is purposely not campaigning here. Ask yourself, if anyone were running a campaign to win, why would they opt out from campaigning in battleground states?

The Internet joke - he is not running a campaign is childish and not taking the seriousness of Trump who may be on to something. He gained the most GOP in U.S. Primary History, doing something different.

Since Trump is not seriously running a campaign, he will get lazier & lazier.  He is simply Hillary's unacceptable foil, who's been set up to alienate everyone.  All he has to do is maintain a very minimalist candidacy until November, when the reality TV show ends, with Hillary getting 85% of the smallest vote we've had in a presidential election since before Roosevelt.

I'll bet Trump is even being paid to do the role of unacceptable foil for Hillary.  Perhaps that's why he won't show is his tax returns. Instead of having a contest between 2 parties, we're being treated to a reality TV show.
Yes!
then clinton wins in a landslide

Neglected to mention I love ROBERTPRESTON. Best musical song without actually being sung...except for maybe Rex Harrison in "My Fair Lady". Though I don't agree with the sentiment so maybe not. There goes my brain again....
No it's not the Supreme Court tie that blocked Obama Immigration plan it was The Federal District Court and the Federal Court of Appeals.
oh, come on. how many times have you used "hoist on your own petard"?
Not even Trump knows Trumps positions.  Trump gives the whole concept of positions the finger.  That's what his supporters love about him.
Thanks, John, me boy, For the clip of TOGOM (1959) by The Crew-Cuts!
So nice to see you here, my friend.
Thank you, Mac K, for calling me friend!  :-)
To that Old WP GANG of mine, always so NEARTO my heart, I'm personally of the opinion that 17A REAWOKEN and it's clue "Brought out of Hibernation" is exceedingly applicable to yours truly!  :-)

The Senate passed a bipartisan immigration reform bill in 2012. A majority of the members of the House of Representatives were prepared to vote in favor of the Senate bill. The only reason we don't have immigration reform is that Republicans in the House refused to let the Senate bill come to the floor of the House for a vote. Now explain to us again how Obama is responsible for the House Republican leadership's refusal to allow a vote.

I wish people would pay attention. There was no court ruling. None. The only thing that happened was that the injunction against the executive order (from the district court in Texas) was not overturned.

Are you kidding? Of course there are derogatory terms for the male equivalent of queen bees. BSD for example has been around for a long time. Big swinging short for Richard. These are the domineering, competitive men who have to be alpha at all costs. They often marry queen bees and become power couples.
I think Sheryl Sandberg has been very fortunate in life, except for her recent tragic loss of her husband. She rose to the top in an industry that is particularly hard on women. But I don't think that makes her an expert on how other women should think or act, and unfortunately that seems to be how she is being marketed and is marketing herself.

But they don't, they just double down. When was the last time you heard a 65-year old Trump supporter, someone who lost his union protection, lost his income and then spiraled down, ever say - "Gosh, maybe voting for that Reagan guy and setting in motion 30+ years of regressive economic policies wasn't such a good idea'? Yeah, never. It is always someone else's fault.
Exactly! And have we ever had to accept the consequences of Obama...
You and they both, Peter. What goes around comes around. Hope it stays away from here. Scary stuff.
You got to accept the voters' option. And then, they have to accept the consequences.

@ Thomas Taber

The Third World is the Third World because 50% of their population, women, has no basic human rights, but go ahead and pretend the West caused that too.
You must mean wealth and jobs to China, otherwise the third world people would remain in their now "well-off" places.

Globalization is not a choice. It is the natural path of balance for the human race. Kicking and screaming will not stop it. Isolationism, bigotry, fear of foreigners will possibly slow it slightly, but will not stop a necessary evolution. If we are to survive as a human kind, we must come together globally, protect our planet, feed all people and accept our global commonalities and responsibilities and cooperate. It seems the early 21st century may go down in history as the last gasp and desperate grab of the old world trying to hold on to cultural purity, antiquated traditions and superiority complexes. Or perhaps there will be no history. The kicking and screaming may lead to guns and bombs and the human race may obliterate itself rather than embrace its necessary oneness.
Brexit, Trump, Putin, Fundalmental Islamics - this is the old world digging its feet into the sand, lying, bullying, murdering in an attempt not to move. Fear of change when change is the natural course.
It seems it will get far worse before it gets better. For the children of our children and so forth let us hope it does get better, instead of simply blowing it up.
Good - self determination in action. All that globalization has achieved is cheaper trinkets in exchange for exporting first world wealth and jobs to the third world. Time to reverse these trends.
Stunning.  Even though Parliament will still have to act, Europe will never be the same.

And a good thing it is. The Brittish empire was not a good thing. If you recall we in the USA exited The British Empire when it trampled our rights.  Now it is the globalist that are trampling the English people's rights and they have voted for freedom.  There will always be an England!

Wales voted to leave; Scotland and Ireland voted stay. The Scots will probably revisit their independence vote and Ireland faces the possibility of an international border between the north and the republic.

I would love nothing more than the ENGLISH to have a vote for independence.
Because that's a "yes" vote waiting to happen.
Goodbye to the United Kingdom, say hello to a country called England.
Everything will be fine!

I am minded of that old saw: Be careful what you wish for; you might get it.

Buckle up!

and Elke
First TRIAL RUN gave me REGINA (on all our coins), EGGNOG, FIRELANE , ROBERT PRESTON ,ASTERS. LEGALPAD and Mr.Rand gave me LAKEVIEW TERRACE. That YIELDed a D- and W- and a lucky guess led to DON'T LET ME DOWN (it didn't).
ROBERT (not Bob) PRESTON also was in a Paramount film :"North West Mounted Police", which premiered Oct. l940 (not NOVEMER) in REGINA, Saskatchewan. It made the list of 50 worst films of all time.
Martin mentioned an upcoming imbibition of SALINE. Lay in a supply of AMSTEL beer for later consumption, even if a bit PRICEY. YULELOGs and EGGNOG are not in season now.
Had trouble with ELO?ELA and REAWA?OKEN.
Never thought of "bras" being "two-piece". Durstn't say my thought.

Am happy that I can PASS THE TIME doing this nice puzzle while watching the BBC forecasting (9pm PST) "UK Votes to Leave ". Wonder what it will BREW UP , for that EMPIRE-----NATION and the rest of us.

It will be a long night.

Yes, 9/11 and Bush's opportunism afterwards combined are the turning points in my mind. Before that we were heading for a recession with the tech bubble burst, nothing nice but nothing big. Of course many other factors involved but that would be pivotal moment in my mind.

Rogox:

You may be right. Or not. Or right for some people, but not others.

The book that I've recommended was very thought provoking for me on several fronts.

1. It positions "collapse" as a normal process of simplifying/reducing unsustainable complexity. Unlike many theories of collapse, it rejects the more common morality-based explanations. In other words, it can be read from an almost non-partisan, "scientific" perspective.

2. It points out that "collapse" has different impacts on different parts of society. For example, it claims that segments of Roman society actually welcomed the "barbarians", because they essentially offered a "better deal" than the Roman elites.

3. It compares the collapse of several different civilizations, not just the Roman Empire.

4. It examines and challenges a range of common collapse theories.

It is only one of many books on the topic, but should be of great interest to anyone trying to make sense of the world today.

Tim:

Thanks. The book sounds interesting. I'm putting it on my reading list.

I would encourage you to consider reading the book by Tainter. It might give you a slightly different perspective on Roman collapse and a comparison to the collapse of other societies. It was eye-opening for me in that regard.

My take is that we are witnessing the weakening of a system, yet the failure of the system is not pre-ordained. In other words, if the system can be modified, we can forestall the decline.

Brexit success is another sign that we live in the age of political dis-integration. In fact, we are probably still in the early stages of this process.

Dis-integration can be viewed as neither good nor bad, but rather the normal outcome when the costs of integration exceed the benefits.

“The Collapse of Complex Societies” by Joseph Tainter is a fascinating book which provides a framework for understanding the dis-integration process. It is a must-read for anyone who would like to understand the causes and process of “collapse” from a systemic perspective.

They came very close last time. But remember, Scotland is not remotely affected as much as England is by massive immigration, foreigners, the welfare state, etc. They think they will continue to be exempt, get benefits from the EU but at no cost (which has been the case so far). They are wrong, but they probably have to learn this on their own.

@Tracy: fascist aggressors? who? and against WHOM? what fascism?

It's almost funny how the left uses the term "fascism" to mean "anyone they don't like or agree with".

And what RACISM? The minorities in Great Britain are mostly from India, Africa, etc. -- former colonies -- that has nothing whatsoever to with (say) the massive influx of workers from POLAND, Greece, etc. who are all WHITE.

Or perhaps you mean the economic migrants from Syria or Turkey or the Middle East? SORRY, TRACY! Islam is a religion, not a race.
It's about time England had a vote for independence.  That would get a yes vote 80/20.

Well, we shall see.

The nationalists have won, and those of us on this side of the Pond have a few months to see what happens when the "Make our Country Great Again" folks actually win and draw themselves inward.

Don't be surprised to see Scotland vote again on whether to leave the United Kingdom ... a SCEXIT if you will.
You seem to be overreacting. Are you in danger of losing your job or being deported?

That was a very shallow reason to give up your US citizenship, then -- wasn't it? You should move somewhere because you love the place, have family & friends there, and a good job. Not because one political scheme or another, as those change over one's lifetime.

Your decision was about as logical as those American lefties who always claim to be moving to Canada, because they don't want a Republican in the White House.

I don't think this is final. Referendums don't hold real power, that belongs with Parliament.

When people wake up tomorrow and realize that Brexit means Scexit (Scotland leaving) and Scexit means the end of the UK, it could trigger a vote of no-confidence in the government (if pro-remain Tories voted along side Labor). This might happen - but it means putting country before party for those Tories, and ironically, Cameron would be one of those voting against the government.

In the meantime, Cameron would have to step down in favor of a pro-Brexit MP.

A vote of no confidence would mean a new general election. In that election a vote for Tories means REAL brexit but also means dissolving the country for real. We can assume that the destruction of the UK would cause many patriotic tories to vote Labor on that one. A Labor lead government would never leave the EU.

That Labor lead coalition would also have to make deals with Scotish nationalist for a more Federated form of UK. That is probably fitting.

Meanwhile we can expect some fallout over on the EU side too leading to a more Confederated EU. That is probably more fitting as well.

The EU was probably 150 years ahead of its time and should go back to being a European Community or EC.

Since the French Revolution, NO national identity has been willing to settle for anything other than self government. That's a hard reality of history that the EU has run into. The Eurocrats got WAY too far out ahead of themselves.

My heart is bleeding.... As an American ex-pat I moved to the UK in the early 2000's to be part of an inclusive Europe. Now my adopted home has become an exclusionist nation and I am scare for my children what that means for their future.
This is truly tragic, and will have long term devistating consequences.
